H0.text: The rate of water flow in a stream was the feature of stream erosion most likely being demonstrated when a water hose was left running on a pile of dirt.

H1.text: The time it takes for deposition to occur along a stream is the feature of stream erosion most likely being demonstrated when a water hose is left running on a pile of dirt.

H2.text: How layers of rocks and soil are formed along a stream is the feature of stream erosion most likely being demonstrated by a water hose left running on a pile of dirt.

H3.text: How water shapes a stream over time is the feature of stream erosion most likely being demonstrated when a water hose was left running on a pile of dirt.

A4.text: Where the river flow is fast, more particles are picked up than dropped. Where the river flow is slow, more particles are dropped than picked up.

A5.text: Sediment motion can create self-organized structures such as ripples, dunes, or antidunes on the river or stream bed.

A6.text: Hydraulic action, most generally, is the ability of moving water (flowing or waves) to dislodge and transport rock particles.

A7.text: Hydraulic action can also cause the breakdown of river banks since there are water bubbles which enter the banks and collapse them when they expand.

A8.text: In all stages of stream erosion, by far the most erosion occurs during times of flood when more and faster-moving water is available to carry a larger sediment load.

A9.text: Erosion is the action of surface processes (such as water flow or wind) that removes soil, rock, or dissolved material from one location on the Earth's crust and then transports it to another location where it is deposited.
